commentBody:

Not sure how bad these crosswords can get before it‚Äôs time to give up a 40-year hobby. It‚Äôs not enough to violate other longstanding conventions like not reusing clue words in answers; now open use of profanity is considered acceptable. 

Could Fagliano at least warn us solvers of crosswords that violate traditional conventions‚Äîwhether of eschewing vulgarity, the breakfast rule, not reusing clue words in answers, etc.‚Äîso those of use who can‚Äôt stand this incompetency can skip it? Just an asterisk in the app, maybe? It could even be an optional app setting.

LESBIANBAR was in fact in poor taste simply because it assumes a gender binary. For opposites to attract (or in this case, not), there must be clearly defined poles with some kind of midpoint‚Äîbut gender and attraction are fluid and occupy broad and vaguely defined spheres of possibility, which is what makes them wonderful and expansive. This clue reduced that beauty and the lived experiences of millions to a na√Øve and lazy implied construct of man and woman. Further, Lesbian Bars, like other queer spaces, are about far more complex interactions and community socialization than just romantic or sexual attraction, further making this clue pretty poor by any standards.

Disappointing.

I think CHARLIE BUCKET had me focused on sweet treats, because I asked myself, what‚Äôs another kind of chip? ‚ÄúChocolate chips!‚Äù I answered. And who makes the chocolate chip cookies you might see in a recipe on your computer? ‚ÄúWhy, an online baker, of course!‚Äù Hey, it seemed reasonable at the time.  At least I refrained from using my first thought for 2D‚Äôs ‚Äú#2‚Äù. I think you can probably guess what that was.

41A, however, came to me without a second‚Äôs hesitation, because I got one of those today! Yay, democracy! (I‚Äôm hoping I can still say that four years from now.)

It was supposed to be punny, I guess, but really, how are men and women , and only men and women, opposites, exactly - because that's what's being implied? Is it some of the Mars/Venus trope BS? Also, character opposites attract for all genders and identities, don't they?

Anyway, I found this puzzle very hard in places, and not in an enjoyable way. NE and SW was easy, SE less so, and NW almost defeated me. I needed trivia lookups for some 5 entries.

I've never heard of CHARLIE BUCKET and as a dog person with a chocolate lab for his best friend I really wanted the clue to be about dogs. The column explained the entry to me... Impossibly arcane to somebody who's never seen the movie, like me. It's not at all popular over here.

Also, dryers are not common in Poland, so DRYER SHEET I had to get from crosses. Most of us live in apartments 50-70 m¬≤ (our flat is 90 m¬≤, which is huge by Warsaw standards and unaffordable for most people), we do our laundry in our bathrooms, usually, and they are smaller than in the US - a typical bathroom is ca. 5 m¬≤, and many are smaller than that. You can't fit two huge devices into a room of that size. Very few people have space for a laundry room. On top of that, dryers or combo washers/dryers are expensive to buy and run, given European electricity costs.

Let me add my voice to the chorus of those who found the clue to LESBIAN BAR one of questionable . . . taste? accuracy? a comment by @Andrzej, below, sums things up pretty well. In the meantime, it is worthy to note that there are only a handful of Lesbian bars left in the US--somewhere between 15 and 40. The Lesbian Bar Project--a video project (sponsored by Jagermeister) dedicated to documenting the remaining bars--counts 34. https://www.lesbianbarproject.com/ Of course, this all depends on how one defines "Lesbian Bar"--a particular Italian restaurant in Ferndale, MI, is particularly popular with Lesbians--but also with heterosexuals and queer men. Does this make it a Lesbian restaurant? Back in the day, however, I spent more evenings in Ye Olde Gaye Bars, packed onto the dance floor like sardines--but packed in sweat (and pheromones) instead of in oil. But the world has changed, and so have I. Now, 11:00pm on a Saturday night is more likely to find me sitting home, getting a head start on Sunday's puzzle. Or seeing who died this week in Midsomer, on PBS. Or more likely, in bed. I hope this isn't TMI. I‚Äôm going to try to explain lines on a sphere one more time once and for all. If I give you two points on a piece of paper and ask you to draw the line between them you will get out a straight edge and connect them. If I draw a curve between them and ask you if that‚Äôs a straight line you will say no, because it‚Äôs not the shortest distance. Miami and Lagos are both near the Tropic of Cancer. If I ask you to fly between them in the shortest distance you WON‚ÄôT fly along the Tropic of Cancer‚Äîyou will fly along the great circle connecting them (the one that cuts the globe exactly in half). The Tropic of Cancer is thus like a curve in the sphere and the great circle is a straight line. And all great circles on a sphere meet every other great circle twice (for that you are going to have to try visualizing yourself). THAT is what that clue means and why it is strictly speaking correct although admittedly esoteric.

This to the various commentators prompted by my earlier (erroneous) claim that the answer to clue to 51 Down regarding lines on a sphere was wrong:  Actually good old Euclid provides the answer as to why only lines that run through a sphere's "poles" are straight lines.  His definition of a "straight-line" is a line "which lies evenly with points on itself."  I.e., arcs connecting two points on that line must be equal on both sides of the line.  One can then see that this condition is only satisfied by great circles on a sphere, as only such lines would have an equal inclination of the sphere on both sides of the line, and thus equal arcs connecting two points on the line.  Whew!  And I hope this atones for my original mistake.

instead, what we get is, much like LESBIANBAR, the constructor once again insists on delimiting a binary that is little more than a right wing dog whistle, which they torturously seek to make clear by rejecting to include even pronouns their fellow right wing extremists recognize -- like, um, "it" or "they", etc. Instead, constructor simply cannot help but emphasize that the *most fundamental, most inevitable, most inescapable!!!!* dispositive that *must* motivate *any* usage of a pronoun is the binary hierarchy which constructor believes pronouns serve to realize and promote. Again, lines of latitude are not lines in spherical geometry. Lines are the shortest distance between any two points and the shortest distance between two points on a sphere is a great circle. @Adam No, it doesn't mean that. In spherical geometry, a "line" is a "great circle" on the sphere, i.e, a circle whose center is at the center of the sphere. These circles have zero "geodesic curvature", and provide shortest paths between points. Other (smaller) circles on the sphere have positive geodesic curvature, and are not "lines" in the intrinsic geometry of the sphere. So the clue is correct---any two distinct lines on the sphere meet/intersect twice, at a pair of antipodal point on the sphere.
@SP SP, You're conflating the genus "line" with the species "straight-line."  Isn't a parabola a particular kind of curved line?

@Jim -- The Freshness Score is a logarithmic calculation made in the XwordInfo site, comparing the freshness of the answer set on a given day, to that of the answer sets of every NYT puzzle of that day in the Modern Era of the Times puzzle, which began in 1993. The fewer times each answer has appeared, the fresher it's considered. The Freshness Score of a puzzle represents the total of all its answers. The higher the score, the reasoning goes, the less same-old same-old the puzzle feels. You can see the site's explanation for today's puzzle: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Fresh?date=11/1/2024 .

(he dons his chapeau didactique)
So we all know that the term "Lesbian" derives from Sappho, the 6th c. BCE poet from the island of Lesbos. She famously wrote lyric poems expressing her love/lust for other women--but also some addressed to young men. And perhaps those addressed to women were written in an assumed "male voice," as was the convention. Also, she wasn't the only ancient Greek poet from Lesbos--there was her (male) contemporary Alcaeus: together, they were known as the "Lesbian poets." 

By the time ancient Roman love-poets were kicking around, the term "Lesbian" had acquires the connotation of "elegantly romantic"--poets would talk about drinking "Lesbian wine"--even though the wines from Lesbos (at least then) were considered pretty bad. And Catullus addressed his (quite heterosexual) love poems to Lesbia--probably a stand-in name for a Roman aristocrat who was married to someone else.

Today is All-Saint's Day, and one of the most popular hymns for the day is "I Sing a Song of the Saints of God," which was penned in the early 20th c. by one Lesbia Scott--whose parents probably named her after the character in Catullus, and not for some forecast of her future orientations.

(He doffs his chapeau didactique.)
